posts.cooked:
Hi all, love Signal
I‚Äôve used it daily for years, but another obvious feature I see missing is a ‚Äòreport CSAM‚Äô button, or the ability for admins to delete messages sent by other users (less important, but still very useful)
I‚Äôve been (unwisely) monitoring public channels for signal group chat links, and joining every single one I can find. I found some awesome chats and people this way but I‚Äôve also been terrified with what I‚Äôve found.
Some issues I‚Äôve noticed:

  1. Raids : Malicious users can join public group chats and send CSAM, up until they are removed (moderation nightmare!!)
  2. CSAM focused group chats. I‚Äôve seen PBs of CSAM sent on signal now, I‚Äôve even reported it directly to signal security email. I have seen at least 50k unique users in these group chats. I don‚Äôt expect signal to monitor public group chats, but since spam reports are accepted, I do expect signal to accept CSAM reports. It might be a bad idea to ban every user though, I‚Äôm not really sure what strategy should be taken to decide on who to ban. Maybe banning every one of them isn‚Äôt a bad idea. Comment your suggestions?
  3. CSAM sticker packs, self explanatory
  4. CSAM profile pictures, self explanatory

I won‚Äôt link any CSAM group chats here, but if signal staff are interested in some examples, search for my email " CSAM reporting on signal" sent to security@signal.org , I can send a ton more examples (seriously at least 800 group chats, ranging from 100-1000 users)
I think making this issue public is the only way to give feedback to signal and influence signal since they ignored my email‚Ä¶ Please like and share if you are interested in seeing this fixed.

Signal, please add a report CSAM button
And maybe make it include media / recently sent messages from the user (like whatsapp), and maybe the user‚Äôs profile data
At least so you can delete group chats and ban users? So you don‚Äôt host TBs on TBs of CSAM? You already ban spam?

posts.cooked:
Ability for group admins to delete any message for everyone Feature Requests
If someone joins your group and posts CSAM, would you argue that removing such material is ‚Äúcensorship‚Äù or that it‚Äôs for the safety (and sanity) of everyone involved to purge it as soon as possible. Having group moderation capabilities is not ‚Äúcensorship‚Äù. It‚Äôs fundamental group safety.

@Soatok Dreamseeker :
If someone joins your group and posts CSAM, would you argue that removing such material is ‚Äúcensorship‚Äù or that it‚Äôs for the safety (and sanity) of everyone involved to purge it as soon as possible.

Having group moderation capabilities is not ‚Äúcensorship‚Äù. It‚Äôs fundamental group safety

link_counts.title: Ability for group admins to delete any message for everyone

posts.cooked:
Group moderation capabilities would be great and I think, admins should be able to delete messages for everyone, leaving behind a ‚Äúgravestone‚Äù indicating by whom the message was sent and by whom it was deleted. This way, it is clearly visible to everyone when this happens too often and members can decide to open a new group with a different admin if they believe that there is censorship going on.

I think having such a CSAM report button would be great, but I don‚Äôt think the implementation is possible within the signal framework. In contrast to users sending normal spam messages (which can be reported) there is no way to recognize CSAM by frequency of messages alone. To do this, viewing message content is necessary, which signal can not do currently and also most likely will never implement because it goes against the fundamental principles of signal. Even if this were implemented, it is also unclear what the consequences should be for users distributing CSAM.

Since possession of a signal account is purely based on possession of a phone number, banning that number is not really a good solution, since in this case any other person receiving ownership of this number in the future would also be banned. Plus, these people could just use a new number, since if they are smart they aren‚Äôt using their primary number anyway or at least don‚Äôt have visibility turned on. Depending on the country and provider, it is very common for a number to go to a new owner quickly and therefore the risk would be high for random people being banned.

Deleting the corresponding account could be an option, but it‚Äôs very easy to just set it up again and since these groups are public, getting back in would be very easy. The same goes for deleting a group with a lot of CSAM in it. It can easily be reestablished. There is also a risk that signal would delete groups with a hundred harmless people and one person hijacking this group with CSAM that hasn‚Äôt been removed quickly enough.

Generally, it would be great if there was a good solution, but unfortunately I think this will not be happening/possible anytime soon.

posts.name: Arik
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôm all for it, and I‚Äôve outlined my opinion in another thread, here:

Ability for group admins to delete any message for everyone Feature Requests
I would like to make the definitive argument for allowing admins to delete any message in a group they admin, regardless of how old it is. The role of an administrator A group belongs to its administrators (usually one of them created the group in the first place). A group‚Äôs character depends (or should depend) on the administrators. The admins can name the group, set the topic of the group, and be selective about the people they allow in the group. Their role is to shape the group in their im‚Ä¶

link_counts.title: Ability for group admins to delete any message for everyone

posts.cooked:
I think that a fundamental question to ask is whether all of this is even Signal‚Äôs responsibility.

Wouldn‚Äôt it make more sense to send group links of groups that distribute such material to law enforcement?

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
TeeJay82:

Wouldn‚Äôt it make more sense to send group links of groups that distribute such material to law enforcement?

And NCMEC National Center for Missing & Exploited Children

Signal would just forward the information to both anyway, and shutting down the group doesn‚Äôt stop it from happening permanently; arrests and prison sentences do that.

desert_nip:

I think having such a CSAM report button would be great, but I don‚Äôt think the implementation is possible within the signal framework

Related : SimpleX blog: SimpleX network: large groups and privacy-preserving content moderation
" * How do server operators prevent abuse of their servers and how these measures will evolve without any compromises to privacy and end-to-end encryption?"

Related : https://faq.whatsapp.com/414631957536067
‚ÄúWhen you report someone, WhatsApp receives up to five of the last messages they‚Äôve sent to you. The user or group won‚Äôt be notified. WhatsApp also receives the reported group or user ID, information on when the message was sent, and the type of message sent (image, video, text, etc.), as well as how the first contact was initiated between you and the reported group or user.‚Äù

Avitus:

Signal would just forward the information to both anyway, and shutting down the group doesn‚Äôt stop it from happening permanently; arrests and prison sentences do that.

Good enough for me, no need to shut down the groups, just forward a snippet of evidence, the group chat link (since these are all public), and user IDs (if possible? Idk how signal works) to copsü§∑

TeeJay82:

I think that a fundamental question to ask is whether all of this is even Signal‚Äôs responsibility.

Oh I definitely believe it definitely is. I need either the ability for admins to delete messages from other users sent in group chats, or the ability to report users who join my public group chats and spam csam (see : Raid)
Signal is the only platform I know of that is lacking this functionality, maybe Teleguard or Kik are just as rotten.
Approve to join and ‚Äúdont auto download media‚Äù are great at mitigating this problem, but don‚Äôt solve it.

anon35358343:

So you don‚Äôt host TBs on TBs of CSAM?

This is a legitimate problem. I donate to signal because I love it, I dont donate to signal so it can plarform CSAM.

posts.edit_reason: 2 posts were merged in by Herohtar

posts.cooked:
anon35358343:

Oh I definitely believe it definitely is.

But why? The whole point of Signal is knowing next to nothing about their users so that they can‚Äôt be coerced into cooperation with law enforcement. Unfortunately this protects criminals as well as people living in oppressive regimes.

Acknowledging responsibility by adding a report feature would open up a whole can of worms. Because why stop with CSAM? It would put Signal in the position where they‚Äôd have to define what ‚Äúcrime‚Äù is. And if they defer to local laws it‚Äôs game over for oppressed minorities.

TeeJay82:

And if they defer to local laws it‚Äôs game over for oppressed minorities.

I dont see how this follows, this is about CSAM, not crime moderation. I dont advocate for accepting or enabling nazi or terrorism or vulgarity or threats of violence reports, soley CSAM.
I understand the fear of compromising Signal‚Äôs mission. I believe Signal is responsible for platforming csam, not acknowledging this is practically condoning it. This is a moral imperative.
I‚Äôm fine if signal doesn‚Äôt moderate it, maybe banning users is out of the question, maybe making a list of users who post CSAM is out of the question. Much like on simplex, users should be able to notify servers that are platforming CSAM that they are platforming CSAM. It should be as easy as clicking a button to forward a report to NCMEC. I don‚Äôt believe there are any legal requirements/laws for a platform who accepts CSAM reports to also accept other kinds of extreme reports (terrorism, threats of violence). Signal is already required to follow the laws of where it is hosted. The risk of legislation has always been present. This does not increase that risk beyond it‚Äôs current state.

TeeJay82:

The whole point of Signal is knowing next to nothing about their users so that they can‚Äôt be coerced into cooperation with law enforcement

This is a very narrow exception
Signal wouldnt be forced to cooperate with law enforcement any more than they are currently, which I believe they are forced to cooperate with law enforcement on extreme crimes already, though of course signal has very little metadata it can provide them. CSAM reporting can maintain this minimal data sharing. CSAM is univerally condemned, unlikely to be co-opted to compare to ‚Äúcrimes‚Äù. Signal could publicly commit to removing this reporting system if any attempts to co-opt into broader moderation it are made. Signal could publicly commit to exit markets where these demands are made (eg. EU demanding client side automatic CSAM scanning, I hope Signal would already exit that market if pressured to implement, only relying on user initiated reporting). Again, CSAM is universally condemned, Signal already has limited data sharing, CSAM reporting can maintain this. But, the whole point of CSAM reporting would be to compromise the privacy of the CSAM poster.

TeeJay82:

Unfortunately this protects criminals as well as people living in oppressive regimes.

Sorry I don‚Äôt understand this either, how does protecting child predators protect oppressed minorities living in oppressive regimes? This is specifically about child predators.
I could see this if there are any laws that require platforms who accept CSAM reports to also accept ‚Äúhate crime‚Äù /etc reports, im unaware of any such laws, but if they existed I assume they would apply to all platforms, and signal would already be banned in such regimes. I believe the risk of legislation would not be any greater than it is currently.
I believe signal is already cooperating with law enforcement to its fullest extent possible, yes signal collects minimal metadata, I don‚Äôt see how accepting CSAM reports would enable collection beyond what is currently possible, except data narrowly relevant to users posting CSAM. Signal‚Äôs cooperation is minimal by design, CSAM reporting can preserve this. Signal is already publicly commited to resisting censorship and moderation demands. CSAM reports could be anonymized to the maximum extent possible, and/or signal could refuse to log data, and/or forward reports without storage, and/or report data could be encrypted with a key that only NCMEC can use. External pressures are a risk but a carefully designed system can minimize the risks. This could only make it an easier UX to combat CSAM, rather than having to manually visit some other website/app/tool to report CSAM.

I believe the moral imperative of CSAM reporting justifies implementing rigorous safeguards to protect minorities.
Failure to implement a CSAM reporting system only makes signal a haven for CSAM, maybe even better than tor.

TeeJay82:

Because why stop with CSAM? It would put Signal in the position where they‚Äôd have to define what ‚Äúcrime‚Äù is.

You can stop with CSAM. I‚Äôm not aware of instances where the definition of CSAM is used for something not legitimately repugnant, unlike ‚Äúterrorism‚Äù or ‚Äúnational security threat‚Äù. Perhaps the only wiggle room is in places where pictures of children performing sexual acts (including AI) is illegal but depictions in drawings are not (like in Japan).

anon35358343:

It should be as easy as clicking a button to forward a report to NCMEC.

What would be in this report?

A few days ago, France passed a law criminalising anti-Zionist statements.
No thanks, I don‚Äôt want to be censored at every turn and denounced for certain comments that may not please others.

I do think that there is a difference between Signal enforcing CSAM moderation/censorship versus Signal empowering group admins to do the enforcing.

Users are already able to block other users. Group admins can be given powers which would help to prevent CSAM distribution that do not compromise end-to-end encryption.

anon35358343:

I dont see how this follows, this is about CSAM, not crime moderation.

anon35358343:

soley CSAM

QuickBanana:

You can stop with CSAM.

Isn‚Äôt this the big misunderstanding we always accused politicians of making with regards to encrypted messaging?
If the ability to moderate ‚Äúsomething‚Äù is introduced, then it is simply not possible, however much one might want it to be, for the same or worse type of moderation to be eventually applied (perhaps by force) to other ‚Äúsomethings‚Äù, even though we never intended this to happen.

anon35358343:

just forward a snippet of evidence

What is this ‚Äòsnippet of evidence‚Äô, how is it obtained and what does it include?

anon35358343:

Sorry I don‚Äôt understand this either, how does protecting child predators protect oppressed minorities living in oppressive regimes?

It‚Äôs slippery slope. Now Signal can respond to all data request ‚ÄúWe do not gather any user data and have nothing to give you. Period.‚Äù Add CSAM reporting and they‚Äôll say ‚ÄúWell, you make exception for CSAM so why not for X?‚Äù, and any pressure for logging, reporting and ‚Äúbenevolent‚Äù access for law enforcement (aka backdoors) will increase hundredfold.

The first step is always the hardest. Let one exception exist and the next thing you know, you‚Äôll be policing also terrorism, drugs, arms trafficking,money laundering, racism, sexism, illegal abortions and political jokes unapproved by government.

You can have security for everyone, including very small percentage of bad people or you can start having exceptions and very soon you won‚Äôt have security for anyone.

Also, we shouldn‚Äôt forget what we learned during the discussions about EU chat control. Most of this material is not shared through messengers. So you would compromise a large user base for catching just a very small minority of criminals.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
QuickBanana:

I‚Äôm not aware of instances where the definition of CSAM is used for something not legitimately repugnant, unlike ‚Äúterrorism‚Äù or ‚Äúnational security threat‚Äù.

unfortunately you only need to look as far as the United States to see attempts to define certain groups of people as pornography, which would make any interaction of said people with children CSA (not to mention children who are themselves members of said group). laws aren‚Äôt and never were a good standard for morality or even for the definition of words.
with how much i find this one of the most heinous forms of harm done to children, it is still clear to me that governments should not be trusted with its definition.

that is not to mention that when ‚Äúsmart‚Äù moderation is involved, we get stories like Google ruining the life of a father for sending pictures of his son to a doctor.

it is clear to me that the existing report abilities, in addition for the ability for admins to delete messages from everyone which i advocate for, are essentially the only trustworthy options.

if anyone ever encounters such vile material, i recommend they contact professionals immediately and ask them how best to help bring perpetrators to justice, rather than try and plead Signal for solutions that will not work and which could have extreme negative consequences.

link_counts.title: Ability for group admins to delete any message for everyone
Google Flagged Parents' Photos of Sick Children as Sexual Abuse

posts.cooked: Even if any account or content is deleted by mods, how will Signal sent content to relevant authorities? If I remember correctly other platforms are able to look at the hash and flag it. But without looking you can‚Äôt flag. You might ban a user from a group but him or her can make a new user name to circumvent this, no? Or can you ban phone numbers, without actually seeing them - due to new updated username things?

Honestly admins being able to moderate their chats through the ability to delete messages sent from other users is good enough for me
I don‚Äôt care for this complicated reporting system since reports can be made directly to the users local agencies, if the user really wants to initiate such a report
But still it would still be a nice feature if signal community supports it, I dont see the privacy of csam group chats as worth preserving, but I understand these are real dangers, not just armchair paranoia.
